PT J
AN ZOOR14912069733
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Elektroeuphaea gen.n., the oldest representative of the modern
   Epallaginae from Eocene Baltic amber (Odonata: Zygoptera: Epallagidae).
AU Nel, Andre (anel@mnhn.fr) 
   Krzeminski, Wieslaw
   Szwedo, Jacek
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 129-140
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Elektroeuphaea flecki gen.n. sp.n., the oldest representative of the
   modern damselfly subfamily Epallaginae, is described from the Middle
   Eocene Baltic amber. This study confirms a Palaeocene age (or older) for
   the Epallagidae, previously supported by the presence of representatives
   of Eodichrominae from the Palaeocene-Eocene Mo-clay Formation of Denmark
   and from Baltic amber.
C1 Nel, Andre; Museum Natl Hist Nat, CNRS, CP 50,45,Rue Buffon, Paris,
   F-75005, France, France.
EM anel@mnhn.fr
RI Szwedo, Jacek/B-4774-2013; Szwedo, Jacek/O-1442-2019
OI Szwedo, Jacek/0000-0002-2796-9538; Szwedo, Jacek/0000-0002-2796-9538;
   Krzeminski, Wieslaw/0000-0001-5685-891X
SC Zoology
SN 1399-560X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Elektroeuphaea [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Elektroeuphaea flecki [Poland /  / new species; Described from amber]
   [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Epallaginae [Poland /  / oldest record; amber] [Eocene / Middle Eocene /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Odonata
OR Elektroeuphaea (Odonata): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Epallaginae, Type
   species Elektroeuphaea flecki, p. 131, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Elektroeuphaea flecki (Odonata): [Sp nov, Poland, Eocene, P. 131,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Epallaginae (Odonata): [Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912069734
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A new Chifengiinae species (Orthoptera: Prophalangopsidae) from the
   Lower Cretaceous Yixian Formation (Liaoning, PR China).
AU Fang, Yan (yanfang@nigpas.ac.cn) 
   Zhang, Haichun
   Wang, Bo
   Zheng, Daran
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 141-147
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB A new species of the family Prophalangopsidae, Ashanga borealis sp.n.,
   is described from the Lower Cretaceous Yixian Fomation (Liaoning
   Province, P.R. China). The male forewing of the new species is similar
   to that of the Middle/Upper Jurassic species Ashanga clara Zherikhin
   1985, but differs from it in possessing a forewing arched anterior
   margin, RS branching more basally, and MP + CuA, with more branches. The
   fossil record of Chifengiinae is reviewed.
C1 Fang, Yan; Chinese Acad Sci, Nanjing Inst Geol & Palaeontol, Nanjing,
   Jiangsu, 210008, China, China.
EM yanfang@nigpas.ac.cn
OI Zhang, Haichun/0000-0003-4553-8317
SC Zoology
SN 1399-560X

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Ashanga borealis [Liaoning /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Chifengiinae [Liaoning /  / systematics; review] [Cretaceous / Lower
   Cretaceous / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria

TI The oldest Palaeoaphididae (Insecta: Hemiptera: Aphidomorpha) from the
   Late Jurassic/Early Cretaceous locality of Khotont (Mongolia).
AU Zyla, Dagmara (zyladagmara@gmail.com) 
   Wegierek, Piotr
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 149-155
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new genus and species of the aphid family Palaeoaphididae,
   Primpalaeoaphis khotontensis gen. et sp.n. is described from the Late
   Jurassic/Early Cretaceous locality of Khotont (Mongolia). This is the
   oldest representative of Palaeoaphididae.

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI The first diplatyid earwig in Tertiary amber (Dermaptera: Diplatyidae):
   A new species from Miocene Mexican amber.
AU Ross, Andrew J. (a.ross@nms.ac.uk) 
   Engel, Michael S.
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 157-166
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The first earwig (Dermaptera) to be described from Mexican (Miocene)
   amber is named Haplodiplatys crightoni Ross & Engel sp.n., represented
   by an adult female and constituting the second record of the basal
   family Diplatyidae in the fossil record. Brief comments are made
   regarding the biogeographic implications of the fossil and the
   evolutionary history of Diplatyidae.
C1 Ross, Andrew J.; Nat Museum Scotland, Dept Nat Sci, Chambers St,
   Edinburgh, Midlothian, EH1 1JF, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM a.ross@nms.ac.uk

AN ZOOR14912069737
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A new cockroach (Blattaria: Caloblattinidae) from the Upper Triassic
   Xujiahe Formation of Sichuan Province, southwestern China.
AU Fang, Yan (yanfang@nigaps.ac.cn) 
   Zhang, Haichun
   Wang, Bo
   Zheng, Daran
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 167-174
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus and species of the cockroach family Caloblattinidae,
   Dazhublattella lini gen. et sp.n., is described from the Upper Triassic
   Xujiahe Formation of Sichuan Province, in southwestern China. The new
   taxon is similar to the Triassic Caloblattina mathildae (Geinitz, 1883)
   (Vrsansky & Ansorge 2007) in the venation and pattern, but differs in
   the less elongated forewing with arched anterior margin. An elemental
   analysis of the wing is undertaken using Energy Dispersive X-ray
   analysis.
C1 Fang, Yan; Chinese Acad Sci, Nanjing Inst Geol & Palaeontol, Nanjing,
   210008, China, China.
EM yanfang@nigaps.ac.cn
OI Zhang, Haichun/0000-0003-4553-8317
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1399-560X

   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Blattodea [China /  / faunal list; systematics] [Triassic / Upper
   Triassic / ]. 
   Dazhublattina [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
   Dazhublattina lini [Sichuan /  / new species; Described from amber]
   [Triassic /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Dictyoptera, Blattodea

   Dazhublattina (Blattodea): [Gen nov, Of family Caloblattinidae, Type
   species Dazhublattina lini, p. 169, Triassic; Fossil].

   Described from amber; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912069738
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Current knowledge of Coleoptera (Insecta) from the Lowermost Eocene Oise
   amber.
AU Kirejtshuk, Alexander G. (kirejtshuk@gmail.com) 
   Nel, Andre
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 175-201
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 8
AB The paper provides an overview on fossil Coleoptera from the Lowermost
   Eocene Oise amber of the Paris Basin (circa 53 million years old). At
   present 45 beetle families have been found from this source. This fossil
   "fauna" has some peculiarities in comparison with other amber deposits.
   Some of these families are not recorded in older outcrops (Pselaphidae,
   Smicripidae, Coccinellidae, Ciidae). Some subfamilies and tribes of
   other groups have their oldest representatives recorded in Oise, i.e.,
   Eurygeniinae (Anthicidae), Inopeplinae (Salpingidae), Trinodini
   (Dermestidae), Megatominae (Dermestidae), Attageninae (Dermestidae),
   Brontinae (Silvanidae), Synchitini (Zopheridae) and Opatrini
   (Tenebrionidae). The genera defined in the "Oise fauna" show various
   geographical links with relatives in the recent fauna. These alternative
   links support that the faunistic composition of the early Eocene had a
   weak zonal differentiation. Scirtes circumcisus sp.n., Boleopsidae
   fam.n:, Boleopsis polinae gen. et sp.n. and Antiphloeus stramineus gen.
   et sp.n. are described. The synonymy of the genera Scirtes Latreille,
   1796 and Eohelodites Hong, 2002 is proposed.
C1 Kirejtshuk, Alexander G.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Emb 1,
   St Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM kirejtshuk@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1399-560X

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Antiphloeus; Boleopsis [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Antiphloeus stramineus; Boleopsis polinae; Scirtes circumcisus [France /
    / new species; Described from amber] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Attageninae; Brontinae; Eurygeniinae; Inopeplinae; Megatominae;
   Opatrini; Synchitini; Trinodini [France / Oise / oldest record] [Eocene
   / Lower Eocene / ]. 
   Boleopsidae [Eocene /  / New family]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Scirtidae, Tenebrionoidea, Anthicidae, Colydiidae, Salpingidae,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Boleopsidae (Cleroidea): [Fam nov, Type genus Boleopsis, p. 185, Eocene;
   Fossil]. 
   Boleopsis (Cleroidea): [Gen nov, Of new family Boleopsidae, Type species
   Boleopsis polinae, p. 189, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Boleopsis polinae (Cleroidea): [Sp nov, France, Eocene, P. 191,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Antiphloeus (Cucujidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Telephanini, Type species
   Antiphloeus stramineus, p. 193, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Antiphloeus stramineus (Cucujidae): [Sp nov, France, Eocene, P. 196,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Brontinae (Cucujidae): [Fossil]. 
   Attageninae (Dermestidae): [Fossil]. 
   Megatominae (Dermestidae): [Fossil].

   199]. 
   Scirtes circumcisus (Scirtidae): [Sp nov, France, Eocene, P. 182,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Eurygeniinae (Anthicidae): [Fossil]. 
   Synchitini (Colydiidae): [Fossil]. 
   Inopeplinae (Salpingidae): [Fossil]. 
   Opatrini (Tenebrionidae): [Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912069739
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Discussion on the systematic position of the oxyteline rove beetle
   Anotylus archaicus Yue, Makranczy & Ren, 2012 (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae).
AU Cai, Chenyang
   Huang, Diying (huangdiying@sina.com) 
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 203-212
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A remarkable oxyteline rove beetle species, Anotylus archaicus Yue,
   Makranczy & Ren, 2012, has recently been described based on several
   exquisitely preserved fossil impressions from the Lower Cretaceous
   Yixian Formation of Liaoning, northeast China. Based on our two new
   specimens and a comprehensive comparison with extant Anotylus species,
   we here suggest that all the previously-reported and new specimens,
   bearing separated gular sutures, sub-contiguous mesocoxae, 5-segmented
   metatarsi, short and poorly-sclerotized abdominal segment II, and
   abdominal segments III-VII each with one pair of paratergites, represent
   a new genus and belong to the basal oxyteline tribe Euphaniini rather
   than Oxytelini. In addition, it was suggested as the earliest fossil
   rove beetle demonstrating sexual dimorphism, the male with strong
   projections of the anterior pronotal angles. However, we suggest that
   the sexual dimorphism is probably misinterpreted, since the so-called
   projections can also be found in a female specimen. The projections
   actually formed when the anterior pronotal margin broke, a condition
   when the head is retracted into the pronotum.
C1 Huang, Diying; Chinese Acad Sci, Nanjing Inst Geol & Palaeontol, 39 East
   Beijing Rd, Nanjing, 210008, China, China.
EM huangdiying@sina.com
SC Zoology
SN 1399-560X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Pseudanotylus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Anotylus archaicus - Yue, Makranczy & Ren 2012 (Staphylinidae):
   [Designated type species for new genus, Pseudanotylus, p. 204]. 
   Pseudanotylus (Staphylinidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Euphaniini, Type
   species Anotylus archaicus Yue, Makranczy & Ren 2012, p. 204,
   Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Pseudanotylus archaicus - (Yue, Makranczy & Ren 2012) (Staphylinidae):
   [Redescription, P. 205; Comb nov, Transferred from Anotylus, p. 205;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912069739
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14912069740
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Mesocoprophilus clavatus, a new oxyteline rove beetle (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae) from the Early Cretaceous of China.
AU Cai, Chenyang
   Huang, Diying (huangdiying@sina.com) 
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 213-220
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Mesocoprophilus clavatus gen. et sp.n., a new rove beetle belonging to
   the Recent subfamily Oxytelinae, is described and illustrated on the
   basis of a well-preserved specimen from the Lower Cretaceous Yixian
   Formation near Huangbanjigou, Beipiao City, Liaoning Province, Northeast
   China. This new genus can be placed in the extant tribe Coprophilini as
   supported by its general habitus, sub-contiguous mesocoxae, 5-segmented
   metatarsi, and abdominal segments III-VII each with two pairs of
   paratergites. In addition, it displays some features resembling the more
   basal tribe Euphaniini, including clavate antennae and short and
   poorly-sclerotized abdominal sternite II.
C1 Huang, Diying; Chinese Acad Sci, Nanjing Inst Geol & Palaeontol,
   Nanjing, 210008, China, China.
EM huangdiying@sina.com
SC Zoology
SN 1399-560X

   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Mesocoprophilus clavatus [Liaoning /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].
   
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae

   species Mesocoprophilus clavatus, p. 215, Cretaceous; Fossil].

   P. 215; Fossil].

AN ZOOR14912069741
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI New mantidflies (Neuroptera: Mantispidae) from the Upper Jurassic of
   Kazakhstan.
AU Khramov, Alexander V. (a-hramov@yandex.ru) 
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 221-230
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Two new species of Mantispidae, Mesithone carnaria sp.n. and M
   monstruosa sp.n., from the Upper Jurassic deposits at Karatau
   (Kazakhstan) are described. These new species are assigned to the
   extinct subfamily Mesithoninae. M protea Panfilov, 1980 and M gracilis
   Panfilov, 1980 are excluded from Mesithone. The family Mesithonidae is
   synonymized with Mantispidae and the relationship of Mesithoninae with
   the four recent mantispid subfamilies is briefly discussed.
C1 Khramov, Alexander V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Paleontol, Profsouznaya St
   123, Moscow, 117997, Russia, Russia.
EM a-hramov@yandex.ru
OI Khramov, Alexander/0000-0002-6888-5162
SC Zoology
SN 1399-560X

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Mantispidae [Kazakhstan /  / systematics] [Jurassic / Upper Jurassic /
   ]. 
   Mesithone carnaria; Mesithone monstruosa [Kazakhstan /  / new species]
   [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Neuroptera

   Fossil].

   Fossil]. 
   Mesithone gracilis - Panfilov 1980 (Neuroptera): [Taxonomic position, P.
   228; Status, P. 221; Fossil]. 
   Mesithone monstruosa (Neuroptera): [Sp nov, Kazakhstan, Jurassic, P.
   224; Fossil]. 
   Mesithone protea - Panfilov 1980 (Neuroptera): [Status, P. 221;
   Taxonomic position, P. 228; Fossil].

AN ZOOR14912069742
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI The oldest representative of Helius Lepeletier & Servile 1828 (Diptera:
   Limoniidae) from Lebanese amber (Early Cretaceous).
AU Kania, Iwona (ikania@univ.rzeszow.pl) 
   Krzeminski, Wieslaw
   Azar, Dany
SO Insect Systematics & Evolution
VL 44
IS 2
PS 231-238
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Helius lebanensis sp.n., the oldest representative of the genus Helms
   Lepeletier & Servile 1828 (Diptera: Limoniidae), from Lebanese amber
   (Early Cretaceous) is characterized, illustrated and described. A
   hypothesis of origin and evolution of the genus Helius with association
   with the Angiosperms is provided and discussed. A complete list of
   fossil limoniids belonging to Helius is given.
C1 Kania, Iwona; Univ Rzeszow, Dept Environm Biol, Zelwerowicza 4, Rzeszow,
   PL-35601, Poland, Poland.

   Kania, Iwona/0000-0002-2325-4308

PT J
AN ZOOR14912066484
DT Article
TI South American Coccinellidae (Coleoptera), Part XV: systematic revision
   of Dilatitibialis Duverger (Coccidulinae; Hyperaspidini).
AU Canepari, Claudio (ccanepari@libero.it) 
   Gordon, Robert D.
   Hanley, Guy A.
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 312
PS 1-91
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Dilatitibialis Duverger (61 species) (Coleoptera: Coccinelidae:
   Coccidulinae; Hyperaspidini) is discussed, species described,
   illustrations provided, and a key to all recognized taxa included.
   Cleothera cognata Mulsant, Cleothera cruciferae Mulsant, Cleothera
   fuscomaculata Mulsant, Cleothera gaynoni Mulsant, Cleothera glyphica
   Mulsant, Cleothera jucunda Mulsant, Cleothera luteola Mulsant, Cleothera
   mulsanti Kirsch, Cleothera oseryi Mulsant, Cleothera poortmanni Mulsant,
   Cleothera scenica Mulsant, Cleothera semicincta Weise, Cleothera
   tropicalis Mulsant, Hinda guttipennis Weise, Hyperaspis carolinae
   Crotch, Hyperaspis ceciliae Crotch, Hyperaspis dilatata Crotch,
   Hyperaspis florifera Vogel, Hyperaspis gravabilis Brethes, Hyperaspis
   hybridula Crotch, Hyperaspis laterinotata Brethes, Hyperaspis silvani
   Crotch, and Hyperaspis suzannae Crotch are transferred to
   Dilatitibialis, becoming new combinations. Lectotypes are designated for
   D. boliviana, D. cognata, D. florifera, D. fuscomaculata, D. gaynoni, D.
   glyphica, D. gravabilis, D. guttipennis, D. luteola, D. jucunda, D.
   mulsanti. D. poortmanni, D. retigera, D. scenica, D. semicincta, and D.
   staudingeri. A total of 38 new species of Dilatitibialis are described:
   Dilatitibialis annie, D. carmen, D. cindy, D. connie, D. crystal, D.
   dawn, D. diana, D. edith, D. edna, D. elaine, D. ellen, D. emily, D.
   ethel, D. fallax, D. florence, D. gladys, D. grace, D. josephine, D.
   kim, D. lillian, D. lois, D. marjorie, D. norma, D. paula, D. peggy, D.
   phyllis, D. rita, D. robin, D. rosa, D. shannon, D. sheila, D. sherry,
   D. sylvia, D. thelma, D. tiffany, D. tina, D. tracy, and D. wendy.
   Corrections are made to titles of previous Parts of this series, as
   follows: South American Coccinellidae, Part XII (Gordon 2007) is changed
   to Part XIII; South American Coccinellidae, Part XII (Gordon et al.
   2013) is changed to Part XIV. Four new synonymies established here:
   Cleothera staudingeri Weise, 1901 = Cleothera semicincta Weise, 1899;
   Hyperaspis pulcherrima Mader, 1954 = Hyperaspis suzannae Crotch, 1874;
   Cleothera boliviana Weise, 1910 = Hyperaspis carolinae Crotch, 1874;
   Cleothera retigera Mulsant, 1850 = Cleothera scenica Mulsant, 1850.
C1 Canepari, Claudio; Soc Entomol Italiana, Via Venezia 1, Milan, I-20097,
   Italy, Italy.
EM ccanepari@libero.it
SC Zoology
SN 0749-6737; 1942-1354
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; Central America; West Indies; South America

PT J
AN ZOOR14912066519
DT Article
TI Systematics and distributions of the genera Cyrtusa Erichson,
   Ecarinosphaerula Hatch, Isoplastus Horn, Liocyrtusa Daffner, Lionothus
   Brown, and Zeadolopus Broun of the United States and Canada (Coleoptera:
   Leiodidae: Leiodinae: Leiodini).
AU Peck, Stewart B. (stewart_peck@carleton.ca) 
   Cook, Joyce
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 310
PS 1-32
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following genera of Leiodini (Coleoptera: Leiodidae: Leiodinae) of
   the continental United States and Canada are reviewed: Cyrtusa Erichson,
   with two species; Isoplastus Horn, with two species (one new);
   Liocyrtusa Daffner, with three species; Lionothus Brown, with five
   species (three new), and Zeadolopus Broun, with four species (all genera
   are in the "Cyrtusa genus group") and Ecarinosphaerula Hatch, with one
   named species (in the "Leiodes genus group"). The new species are
   Isoplastus floridanus Peck and Cook of Florida; Lionothus bidentatus
   Peck and Cook of Texas and Oklahoma, Lionothus exiguus Peck and Cook of
   Florida and Texas, and Lionothus parvoculus Peck and Cook of Arizona and
   New Mexico. Bionomic data on the species are given, and complete known
   distributions are mapped.
C1 Peck, Stewart B.; Carleton Univ, Dept Biol, Ottawa, ON, K1S 5B6, Canada,
   Canada.
EM stewart_peck@carleton.ca
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology

DT Article
TI A new North American species of Microrhagus Dejean, 1833 (Coleoptera:
   Eucnemidae), with a key to the Nearctic species.
AU Otto, Robert L. (tar1672@yahoo.com) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 307
PS 1-6
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Microrhagus brunneus, new species (Coleoptera: Eucnemidae: Melasinae:
   Dirhagini) is described from Arkansas, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana,
   North Carolina, Oklahoma and Wisconsin. Dorsal, ventral and lateral
   habitus, along with male aedeagus are illustrated and a new key is
   provided to distinguish the new species from the four other Microrhagus
   species in the region.
C1 Otto, Robert L.; 2301 Cypress Way,Apt 22, Madison, WI, 53713, USA, USA.
EM tar1672@yahoo.com

   region; North America; USA

   [Kentucky /  / ] [Louisiana /  / ] [North Carolina /  / ] [Oklahoma /  /
   ] [Wisconsin /  / ].

DT Article
TI Sufetula Walker in Florida (Lepidoptera: Crambidae).
AU Hayden, J.E. (James.Hayden@FreshFromFlorida.com) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 296
PS 1-15
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The two species of Sufetula Walker (Lepidoptera: Crambidae) occurring in
   Florida are reviewed based on adult specimens. Sufetula carbonalis n.
   sp. is described, Sufetula diminutalis (Walker) is diagnosed, and they
   are differentiated from related Caribbean species and similar sympatric
   Crambidae. Both are occasional root pests of ornamental palms. Unusual
   structural characters suggest that Sufetula is misclassified in
   Spilomelinae.
C1 Hayden, J.E.; FDACS, Div Plant Ind, POB 147100, Gainesville, FL, 32614,
   USA, USA.
EM James.Hayden@FreshFromFlorida.com
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology
SN 0749-6737; 1942-1354
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Life cycle and
   development; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Sufetula carbonalis [Florida /  / New species]. 
   Sufetula diminutalis [Life cycle / Phenology / Systematics] [Florida / 
   / distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Pyraloidea, Pyralidae
OR Sufetula - Walker 1859 (Pyralidae): [Status, P. 5]. 
   Sufetula carbonalis (Pyralidae): [Sp nov, Florida, P. 5]. 
   Sufetula diminutalis - (Walker 1866) (Pyralidae).

   Mexico are described and figured.

   I-56011, Italy, Italy.

   region; North America

   Cephalocyclus majomaensis; Oscarinus cabreroi [Mexico /  / New species].

   Scarabaeidae
OR Cephalocyclus - Dellacasa, Gordon & Dellacasa 1998 (Scarabaeidae): [Key

DT Article
TI Leaf Beetles of the Cayman Islands (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae).
AU Clark, Shawn M. (shawn_clark@byu.edu) 
   Lillrose, Tiffany
   Belo, Luiz A., neto
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 279
PS 1-41
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Data are presented for 29 chrysomelid species (Coleoptera:
   Chrysomelidae) occurring in the Cayman Islands, West Indies, 26 of these
   not having been reported from these islands previously. Altica
   occidentalis Suffrian is removed from the genus Lysathia Bechyne and
   reinstated in Altica Geoffroy. Chaetocnema perplexa Blake is synonymized
   with Chaetocnema confinis Crotch, new synonymy. Omophoita cyanipennis
   octomaculata (Crotch) is synonymized with Omophoita cyanipennis
   (Fabricius), new synonymy. The following nine species are named and
   described: Apraea luciae, Apraea priscilae, Cryptocephalus catharinae,
   Cryptocephalus kirki, Cryptocephalus paulotigrinus, Longitarsus
   alisonae, Megistops adiae, Nyctiplanctus bifasciatus, Syphrea
   thurstonae, all are new species. Taxonomic notes and a key to species,
   as well as information on plant associations and extralimital
   distribution, are also provided.

PT J
AN ZOOR14912066825
DT Article
TI Cryptic species of Nereididae (Annelida : Polychaeta) on Australian
   coral reefs.
AU Glasby, Christopher J. (chris.glasby@nt.gov.au) 
   Wei, Nu-Wei V.
   Gibb, Karen S.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 27
IS 3
PS 245-264
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 2
U2 21
AB We investigate the presence of cryptic species among three highly
   variable nereidid polychaetes commonly found in Australian coral reefs -
   Nereis denhamensis Augener, 1913, Perinereis suluana (Horst, 1924) and
   Pseudonereis anomala Gravier, 1901 - based on morphological and
   molecular data (mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I, COI, and
   nuclear histone H3). DNA extracted and sequenced from 70 specimens from
   northern Australia and the Philippines indicated the existence of eight
   species: three matched the types of existing species; four are newly
   described (Nereis heronensis, sp. nov., N. lizardensis, sp. nov.,
   Perinereis pictilis, sp. nov. and Pseudonereis anomalopsis, sp. nov.)
   from NE Australia, and one species is described but not named due to
   lack of material. Nereis denhamensis, N. heronensis, sp. nov. and N.
   lizardensis, sp. nov. are distinguished from each other by proboscidial
   paragnath number and morphology of the metamorphosed female. Perinereis
   suluana can only be separated from P. pictilis, sp. nov. by colour
   pattern, while Pseudonereis anomala, P. anomalopsis, sp. nov. and P. sp.
   differ in colour pattern and the number and arrangement of paragnaths.
   Nereis (Lycoris) tydemani from Maluku, Indonesia, is newly synonymised
   with P. anomala. Divergence times estimated using COI indicated that
   speciation in all three groups occurred in the mid Miocene (20-17 +/- 7
   mya), which corresponds to a period of restricted east-west dispersal as
   Australia collided with the Indo-Malay archipelago, followed by range
   expansion opportunities in NE Australia as a result of flourishing coral
   reefs responding to warming seas and rising sea levels.
C1 Glasby, Christopher J.; Museum & Art Gallery Northern Terr, Darwin, NT,
   0801, Australia, Australia.
EM chris.glasby@nt.gov.au
RI Glasby, Christopher J/R-8382-2016
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Marine &Freshwater
   Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1445-5226
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Genetics; Evolution;
   Evolutionary adaptation; Habitat; Marine habitat; Zoogeography; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Nereis denhamensis; Perinereis suluana; Pseudonereis anomala [Molecular
   genetics / Molecular markers / systematics] [Divergence / Divergence
   times / ] [Speciation / Cryptic speciation / ] [Reef habitat / Coral
   reef habitat / ] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [South Pacific /
   Australia / ]. 
   Nereis heronensis [North Pacific / Philippines / New species] [South
   Pacific / Australia, Queensland / ]. 
   Nereis lizardensis; Perinereis pictilis; Pseudonereis anomalopsis [South
   Pacific / Australia, Queensland / New species].

   (marine), P. 255]. 
   Perinereis pictilis (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Australia, Queensland
   (marine), P. 256].

DT Article
TI Phylogeny and taxonomic revision of the spider mite genera Aponychus,
   Paraponychus and Stylophoronychus using morphology (Acari :
   Tetranychidae).
AU Hernandes, Fabio A.
   Feres, Reinaldo J.F.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 27
IS 3
PS 265-281
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Despite their great importance as pests of cultivated plants worldwide,
   members of the family Tetranychidae have never been subjected to a
   thorough cladistic analysis to reveal the history and relationships
   among related genera. Herein, we provide the first phylogenetic analysis
   and taxonomic review of species of the genera Aponychus, Paraponychus
   and Stylophoronychus using morphological characters. The results
   indicate a monophyletic clade uniting the aforementioned genera,
   although none of the three genera were recovered as monophyletic. We
   reinstate the tribe Aponychini as the taxon containing those three
   genera. Aponychus bambusae and A. aequilibris are herein considered
   junior synonyms of Stylophoronychus vannus and A. corpuzae,
   respectively.
RI Hernandes, Fabio Akashi/H-1982-2012
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 1445-5226
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Evolution
DE Aponychus; Paraponychus; Stylophoronychus [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic
   analysis / Systematics]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Aponychini - Rimando 1966 (Acari): [Status, P. 274]. 
   Aponychus (Acari). 
   Aponychus corpuzae - Rimando 1966 (Acari): [Syn nov, Aponychus
   aequilibris Tseng 1990, p. 269]. 
   Paraponychus (Acari). 
   Stylophoronychus (Acari). 
   Stylophoronychus vannus - (Rimando 1968) (Acari): [Syn nov, Aponychus
   bambusae Gupta & Gupta 1990, p. 273].

DT Article
TI Phylogenetic and biogeographic analysis of the genus Caribeacarus (Acari
   : Opilioacarida), with description of a new South American species.
AU de Oliveira Bernardi, Leopoldo Ferreira
   Barbosa Silva, Fernando Augusto
   Zacarias, Mauricio Sergio
   Klompen, Hans
   Ferreira, Rodrigo Lopes
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 27
IS 3
PS 294-306
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The mite order Opilioacarida is widely distributed in the tropical and
   sub-tropical zones of the world, where it is rare and poorly known. On
   the American continent only two genera, 14 species and one subspecies
   are known. This work aimed to describe a new species of Caribeacarus
   from the state of Para, in the eastern part of the Brazilian Amazon. A
   phylogenetic analysis of the species in this genus is also presented,
   and interpreted along with the historical biogeography of this genus in
   Central and South America. A key to the species of Caribeacarus is
   provided.
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1445-5226

   Zoogeography; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI Morphological and molecular insights on Megalothorax: the largest
   Neelipleona genus revisited (Collembola).
AU Schneider, Clement (clement.schneider@mnhn.fr) 
   D'Haese, Cyrille A.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 27
IS 3
PS 317-364
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB The genus Megalothorax Willem, 1900 is redefined along with a
   redescription of the type species M. minimus Willem, 1900 and the
   description of five new species (M. granulosus, sp. nov., M.
   nigropunctatus, sp. nov., M. perspicillum, sp. nov., M. svalbardensis,
   sp. nov. and M. willemi, sp. nov.). We describe and comment on broad
   sets of discriminating characters for Megalothorax systematics. For the
   first time, trichobothria are recorded for Neelipleona, probably of
   generic importance. The described species are provided with DNA data
   (COI, 16S and 28S) and included in a molecular-based phylogenetic
   analysis. The traditional distinction between minimus-group and
   incertus-group is discussed in the light of DNA and morphology
   components. A key to the worldwide Megalothorax species is provided.
C1 Schneider, Clement; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dpt Systemat & Evolut, CP50,45

DT Article
TI A new genus for Chlorodiella longimana (H. Milne Edwards) supported by
   morphology and molecular data, with a preliminary phylogeny of the
   Chlorodiellinae (Crustacea : Decapoda : Xanthidae).
AU Lasley, Robert M., Jr (rlasleyjr@gmail.com) 
   Lai, Joelle C.Y.
   Thoma, Brent P.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 27
IS 4
PS 379-390
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Chlorodiella longimana is the only chlorodielline species presently
   known from the western Atlantic Ocean. Although C. longimana
   superficially resembles other species of the genus in general appearance
   of the carapace, morphological analyses revealed a suite of characters
   that separate it from all other known species of Chlorodiella - in
   particular, ambulatory legs having dactyli with a single tip and a basal
   antennal segment with a lateral flange that extends halfway into the
   orbital hiatus, excluding the antennal flagellum. In addition, a
   phylogenetic analysis of the Chlorodiellinae inferred from three
   mitochondrial markers (12S, 16S, COXI) and a nuclear marker (histone
   H3), confirms that C. longimana is genetically distinct from its
   congeners. A new genus, Ratha, is proposed to accommodate C. longimana.
   In addition, a phylogenetic analysis of six chlorodielline genera
   indicates that the subfamily is polyphyletic as presently defined.
C1 Lasley, Robert M., Jr; Natl Univ Singapore, Dept Biol Sci, 14 Sci Dr 4,
   Singapore, 117543, Singapore, Singapore.
EM rlasleyjr@gmail.com
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1445-5226
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Genetics; Evolution
DE Chlorodiellinae [Molecular genetics /  / systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ].
   
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Chlorodiellinae - Ng & Holthuis 2007 (Brachyura). 
   Chlorodius longimanus - Edwards 1834 (Brachyura): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Ratha, p. 380]. 
   Ratha (Brachyura): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Chlorodiellinae, Type species
   Chlorodius longimanus Edwards 1834, p. 380]. 
   Ratha longimana - (Edwards 1834) (Brachyura): [Redescription, P. 386;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Chlorodiella, p. 386].

AN ZOOR14912070062
DT Article
TI The Meloidae (Coleoptera) of Australasia: a generic review, descriptions
   of new taxa, and a challenge to the current definition of subfamilies
   posed by exceptional variation in male genitalia.
AU Bologna, M.A. (marcoalberto.bologna@uniroma3.it) 
   Turco, F.
   Pinto, J.D.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 27
IS 4
PS 391-427
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 9
AB The seven Australasian genera of blister beetles (Coleoptera : Meloidae
   : Nemognathinae) are reviewed. Included are a key to genera, generic
   synopses and descriptions of two new genera of Nemognathini,
   Australozonitis and Pulchrazonitis, as well as a new monotypic tribe
   Palaestrini, which features a bauplan of male genitalia unique not only
   to the subfamily Nemognathinae but to the entire family. The genus
   Palaestra is redefined to include several Australasian, Asian and
   African species previously assigned to Zonitis. Exceptional variation of
   male genitalia encountered in the Palaestrini challenges current
   subfamily definitions, which are partly based on male genitalic
   structure and correlated sexual behaviour. Generic synopses include
   synonyms, type species, number of species, geographic distribution,
   significant references on taxonomy, life history and morphology, and
   additional notes. Forty-six new combinations are proposed for species
   previously in Zonitis. Distribution and relationship of tribes within
   the Nemognathinae, as well as the biogeography of the Australasian
   Meloidae are outlined and discussed.
C1 Bologna, M.A.; Univ Roma Tre, Dipartimento Sci, Viale G Marconi 446,
   Rome, I-00146, Italy, Italy.

PT J
AN ZOOR14912070064
DT Article
TI Colonisation of the Pacific by Bembidion beetles (Coleoptera :
   Carabidae), with description of Bembidion tahitiense, sp nov from
   Tahiti, French Polynesia.
AU Liebherr, James K. (jkl5@cornell.edu) 
   Maddison, David R.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 27
IS 4
PS 439-449
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Bembidion (Sloanephila) tahitiense, sp. nov. is described from Mont
   Mauru, an isolated massif of Tahiti Nui volcano. Based on evidence from
   seven genes (four nuclear protein-coding, one mitochondrial
   protein-coding, two nuclear ribosomal), its sister group is the
   Australian B. jacksoniense Guerin-Meneville, with which it shares a
   synapomorphic spur on the ostium of the male genitalia. In contrast to
   B. jacksoniense, B. tahitiense is brachypterous, with rounded humeri,
   constricted posterior pronotal margins and convex body form. Examination
   of the seven genes in two species of the Hawaiian subgenus Nesocidium
   Sharp reveals that the sister group of Nesocidium is subgenus Zecillenus
   Lindroth from New Zealand. These two subgenera belong to the Ananotaphus
   complex, a clade inhabiting Australia, New Zealand and Hawaii. The
   relationships of the second Hawaiian subgenus, Gnatholymnaeum Sharp, are
   less clear, although Gnatholymnaeum belongs to the Bembidion series
   (along with Sloanephila and the Ananotaphus complex). Bembidion beetles
   colonised the Society and Hawaiian islands independently from source
   areas in the south-west Pacific. Based on parsimonious reconstructions
   of flight-wing configuration, the Tahitian and Hawaiian colonisations
   involved winged individuals. Colonisation of the Society and Hawaiian
   islands by carabid beetles of two other tribes - Platynini and
   Moriomorphini - follow the dispersal patterns hypothesised for
   Bembidion.
C1 Liebherr, James K.; Cornell Univ, Dept Entomol, Ithaca, NY, 14853, USA,
   USA.
EM jkl5@cornell.edu
OI Liebherr, James/0000-0001-9831-884X
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1445-5226
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Ecology; Habitat
   utilization; Zoogeography; Dispersal; Land zones; Oceanic islands;
   Pacific Ocean islands; French Polynesia
DE Bembidion [Phylogeny / Synapomorphy / systematics] [Habitat colonization
   /  / ] [Dispersal patterns /  / ] [Society Islands / Tahiti / ]. 
   Bembidion (Sloanephila) tahitiense [Society Islands /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Bembidion - Latreille 1802 (Carabidae). 
   Bembidion (Sloanephila) tahitiense (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Society
   Islands, P. 445].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912070065
DT Article
TI Phylogeny of the ophrynopine clade revisited: review of the parasitoid
   sawfly genera Ophrella Middlekauff, Ophrynopus Konow and Stirocorsia
   Konow (Hymenoptera : Orussidae).
AU Vilhelmsen, Lars (lbvilhelmsen@snm.ku.dk) 
   Blank, Stephan M.
   Costa, Valmir A.
   Alvarenga, Thiago M.
   Smith, David R.
SO Invertebrate Systematics
VL 27
IS 4
PS 450-483
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB The rare family Orussidae comprises the only parasitoid sawflies and are
   sister to the Apocrita, the latter comprising most of Hymenoptera.
   Because of this, their morphology and relationships have been
   particularly important for interpreting the morphology of and biological
   transitions within the order as a whole. Within the Orussidae the
   ophrynopines are a comparatively diverse clade with a predominantly
   southern hemisphere distribution. Here, a revised and expanded
   morphological dataset incorporating several new taxa is used to test
   ophrynopine relationships and provide further insights into their
   evolutionary history. The analyses largely corroborate previous results.
   The distribution pattern and the fossil record indicate that the
   ophrynopines radiated in the early Cenozoic in the Australasian-Oceanian
   and the Neotropic regions and later dispersed into the Nearctic, Eastern
   Palaearctic and Indomalayan regions. The South American genus Ophrella
   Middlekauff, 1985 is well supported as a monophyletic genus, whereas
   Ophrynopus Konow, 1897 is paraphyletic with respect to Stirocorsia
   Konow, 1897. Three new species, Ophrella eldorado Vilhelmsen, sp. nov.,
   Ophrynopus Guarani Blank, D. R. Smith & Vilhelmsen, sp. nov., and
   Ophrynopus rupestris Vilhelmsen, Costa & Alvarenga, sp. nov. are
   described. Ophrella lingulata Middlekauff, 1985 is treated as a junior
   synonym of Ophrella amazonica (Westwood, 1874). Stirocorsia is treated
   as a junior synonym of Ophrynopus. The species Ophrynopus apicalis
   (Togashi, 2000), Ophrynopus kohli (Konow, 1897), Ophrynopus maculipennis
   (F. Smith, 1859) and Ophrynopus tosensis (Tosawa & Sugihara, 1934),
   formerly in Stirocorsia, are transferred to Ophrynopus. Revised keys to
   the species of Ophrella, Ophrynopus and the genera in the ophrynopine
   clade are provided. In addition, Orussidae are recorded from Bolivia and
   French Guiana for the first time.
C1 Vilhelmsen, Lars; Nat Hist Museum Denmark, Univ Pk 15, Copenhagen,
   DK-2100, Denmark, Denmark.
EM lbvilhelmsen@snm.ku.dk
RI Vilhelmsen, Lars/A-3396-2013; Vilhelmsen, Lars/AAC-6747-2020; Costa,
   Valmir/N-6371-2013
OI Vilhelmsen, Lars/0000-0002-5593-5722; Vilhelmsen,
   Lars/0000-0002-5593-5722; Costa, Valmir/0000-0003-0122-3567
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1445-5226
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Evolution;
   Land zones; Neotropical region; Oriental region; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; South America

   record] [French Guiana /  / ].

   Ophrella - Middlekauff 1985 (Orussidae): [Key to species, P. 461].

   P. 456]. 
   Ophrella lingulata - Middlekauff 1985 (Orussidae): [Junior synonym, Of

   Ophrynopus apicalis - (Togashi 2000) (Orussidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Stirocorsia, p. 462]. 
   Ophrynopus carinatus - Vilhelmsen & Smith 2002 (Orussidae):
   [Redescription, P. 462]. 
   Ophrynopus guarani - Blank, Smith & Vilhelmsen 2013 (Orussidae): [Sp
   nov, Bolivia, P. 464]. 
   Ophrynopus kohli - (Konow 1897) (Orussidae): [Combination revalidated,
   Transferred back from Stirocorsia, p. 462; New record]. 
   Ophrynopus maculipennis - (Smith 1859) (Orussidae): [Combination
   revalidated, Transferred back from Stirocorsia, p. 462]. 
   Ophrynopus rupestris - Vilhelmsen, Costa & Alvarenga 2013 (Orussidae):
   [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 466]. 
   Ophrynopus tosensis - (Tosawa & Sugihara 1934) (Orussidae): [Combination
   revalidated, Transferred back from Stirocorsia, p. 462; New record]. 
   Stirocorsia - Konow 1897 (Orussidae): [Junior synonym, Of Ophrynopus
   Konow 1897, p. 461, Cited by author as synonymy re-established]. 
   Stirocorsia apicalis - Togashi 2000 (Orussidae): [Referred to,
   Ophrynopus, p. 462].

   462].

   Ophrynopus, p. 462].

DT Article
TI NEBALIA PSEUDOTRONCOSOI N. SP (MALACOSTRACA: LEPTOSTRACA), FROM SOUTH
   KOREA, WITH A PECULIAR SEXUAL DIMORPHISM.
AU Song, Ji-Hun
   Moreira, Juan
   Min, Gi-Sik (luckymadang@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Crustacean Biology
VL 33
IS 1
PS 124-136
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new crustacean, Nebalia pseudotroncosoi n. sp. (Malacostraca:
   Leptostraca), occurs along the southern coasts of Korea. The specimens
   were collected by light traps in harbors where the bottom consisted of
   fine sand with some algal mats. The new taxon is distinguished from all
   other known species of Nebalia by the following characteristics: a
   rectangular compound eye with two to three small distal lobes; an
   antennular flagellum that is clearly shorter than the peduncle, with up
   to 10 articles; the fourth article of the antennular peduncle has only
   two distal thick setae; the antennular scale is nearly oval with a
   length that is 1.8 times the width; the second article of the mandibular
   palp has three distally plumose setae; pleonites 3 to 7 have rounded
   denticles along their posterior dorsal margins; and the protopod of
   pleopod 4 lacks serration along the posterior margin. We discuss sexual
   dimorphism in the genus Nebalia and propose the necessity of describing
   male traits when reporting new species. We also provide partial
   sequences of the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 (CO1) gene
   from the new species that can be used as a molecular diagnostic
   characteristic.
C1 Min, Gi-Sik; Inha Univ, Coll Nat Sci, Inchon, 402751, South Korea, South
   Korea.
EM luckymadang@gmail.com
RI Moreira, Juan/D-4462-2013
OI Moreira, Juan/0000-0002-1374-2033; Song, Ji-Hun/0000-0003-3542-0091
SC Reproductive Biology; Zoology
SN 0278-0372
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Reproduction; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Nebalia [Sex differences / Sexual dimorphism / ]. 
   Nebalia pseudotroncosoi [North Pacific / South Korea / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Nebalia pseudotroncosoi (Phyllocarida): [Sp nov, South Korea (marine),
   P. 126].

DT Article
TI Morphological and Molecular Description of Three New Species of the
   Cyrtophorid Genus Chlamydodon (Ciliophora, Cyrtophoria).
AU Pan, Hongbo
   Li, Lifang
   Al-Rasheid, Khaled A.S.
   Song, Weibo (wsong@ouc.edu.cn) 
SO Journal of Eukaryotic Microbiology
VL 60
IS 1
PS 2-12
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 19
AB This study investigates the morphology and molecular characteristics of
   three new cyrtophorid ciliates isolated from China seas: Chlamydodon
   salinus n. sp., Chlamydodon caudatus n. sp., and Chlamydodon
   paramnemosyne n. sp. Of these, C. salinus n. sp. differs from its
   congeners through a combination of body size, a cross-striated band that
   is not continuous, the presence of 3034 somatic kineties, 1115
   nematodesmal rods, and 13 contractile vacuoles. Chlamydodon caudatus n.
   sp., meanwhile, is characterized by having a conspicuous tail, a
   continuous cross-striated band, 3440 somatic kineties, about 15
   contractile vacuoles, and 2024 nematodesmal rods. Compared with other
   Chlamydodon species, the third new one, C. paramnemosyne n. sp., could
   be identified by its continuous cross-striated band, 1618 somatic
   kineties, 5 contractile vacuoles, and 912 nematodesmal rods. Based on
   the sequence of the small subunit (SSU) rRNA gene, the phylogeny of
   these three new species was analyzed, indicating that they all clustered
   with other congeners to form a monophyletic assemblage. Based on
   previous studies and the present work, a brief revision of the genus
   Chlamydodon is supplied, and a key to aid the identification of
   Chlamydodon species is given.
C1 Song, Weibo; Ocean Univ China, Inst Evolut & Marine Biodivers, Qingdao,
   266003, China, China.
EM wsong@ouc.edu.cn
RI Pan, Hongbo/F-2054-2013; AL-Rasheid, Khaled A S/C-2486-2008; Li,
   Lifang/E-7987-2014; Li, Lifang/G-3939-2015; Pan, Hongbo/L-7928-2017
OI Pan, Hongbo/0000-0001-5047-0463; AL-Rasheid, Khaled A
   S/0000-0002-3404-3397; Pan, Hongbo/0000-0001-5047-0463
SC Zoology
SN 1066-5234
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Chlamydodon caudatus [North Pacific / China, Guangdong / New species]. 
   Chlamydodon paramnemosyne [North Pacific / China / New species]. 
   Chlamydodon salinus [North Pacific / China, Shandong / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Ciliophora, Kinetofragminophorea, Hypostomatia, Cyrtophorida
OR Chlamydodon - Ehrenberg 1835 (Cyrtophorida): [Revision, P. 8; Key to
   species, P. 11]. 
   Chlamydodon caudatus (Cyrtophorida): [Sp nov, China, Guangdong (marine),
   P. 4]. 
   Chlamydodon paramnemosyne (Cyrtophorida): [Sp nov, China (marine), P.
   4]. 
   Chlamydodon salinus (Cyrtophorida): [Sp nov, China, Shandong (marine),
   P. 3].

DT Article
TI Morphological, Ultrastructural, and Molecular Characterization of
   Euplotidium rosati n. sp (Ciliophora, Euplotida) from Guam.
AU Modeo, Letizia
   Petroni, Giulio (gpetroni@biologia.unipi.it) 
   Lobban, Christopher S.
   Verni, Franco
   Vannini, Claudia
SO Journal of Eukaryotic Microbiology
VL 60
IS 1
PS 25-36
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB We combined morphological (i.e. live, stained, scanning, and
   transmission electron microscopy) with morphometric and molecular
   analysis to describe a ciliate species collected from shallow reefs in
   Guam, grown, and maintained in our laboratory. The species was
   recognized as a member of Euplotidium, and compared with established
   species of the genus: Euplotidium itoi Ito 1958; Euplotidium
   psammophilus (Vacelet 1961) Borror 1972; Euplotidium arenarium Magagnini
   and Nobili 1964; Euplotidium helgae Hartwig 1980; Euplotidium prosaltans
   Tuffrau 1985, and Euplotidium smalli Lei, Choi and Xu, 2002. To obtain
   more elements to compare the species, new morphometric data and
   additional SSU rRNA gene sequences of E. itoi and of E. arenarium are
   reported. On the basis of this comparison, we established the new
   species Euplotidium rosati that has a cirral pattern composed of 12
   frontoventral and six transverse cirri, and lacks the left marginal
   cirrus. Euplotidium rosati harbors on its dorsal surface epixenosomes,
   the peculiar extrusive symbionts described in other Euplotidium species.
   The whole body of our observations together with the analysis of the
   data available in the literature leads us to propose a redefinition of
   the genus. The results may also be useful to clarify the tangled
   relationship between Euplotidium and Gastrocirrhus.
C1 Petroni, Giulio; Univ Pisa, Dept Biol, Via A Volta 4-6, Pisa, I-56126,
   Italy, Italy.
EM gpetroni@biologia.unipi.it
RI Petroni, Giulio/B-6086-2008; Modeo, Letizia/G-8771-2017
OI Petroni, Giulio/0000-0001-9572-9897; VANNINI,
   CLAUDIA/0000-0002-6195-695X
SC Zoology
SN 1066-5234
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Taxonomy;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Euplotidium rosati [North Pacific / Guam / New species].

PM 23194299
DT Article
TI Three New Loxophyllum Species (Ciliophora: Pleurostomatida) from China
   with a Brief Review of the Marine and Brackish Loxophyllum Species.
AU Pan, Hongbo
   Gao, Feng
   Lin, Xiaofeng (xlin@scnu.edu.cn) 
   Warren, Alan
   Song, Weibo
SO Journal of Eukaryotic Microbiology
VL 60
IS 1
PS 44-56
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB Recent studies indicate that there is a high diversity of pleurostomatid
   ciliates in the coastal waters of China. Here, three new congeners of
   Loxophyllum, L. caudatum sp. n., L. rugosum sp. n., and L. chinense sp.
   n., are described following observations of live cells and
   protargol-impregnated specimens. All three species usually have two
   macronuclear nodules and prominent warts along the dorsal margin formed
   by clustered extrusomes. In addition, L. caudatum sp. n. is
   characterized by its long conspicuous tail, dot-like cortical granules,
   4 or 5 left and 9 or 10 right kineties, and a single subterminal
   contractile vacuole. Loxophyllum rugosum sp. n. is distinguished by
   possessing three prominent ridges on the left side, 711 right and 57
   left kineties. Loxophyllum chinense sp. n. is characterized by having
   several contractile vacuoles distributed along the ventral margin, 1318
   right and 68 left kineties. The small subunit ribosomal DNA (SSU rDNA)
   sequence similarities among six congeners range from 96.46% to 99.94%.
   Phylogenetic trees based on the SSU rDNA sequences indicate that all
   Loxophyllum spp. form a well-supported monophyletic group. A brief
   review of the marine and brackish Loxophyllum species is supplied and
   one new combination, Litonotus multiplicatus (Kahl 1931) comb. n.
   (basionym Loxophyllum multiplicatum Kahl 1931), and one new name,
   Litonotus dragescoi nom. n. (basionym L. fasciolatus Dragesco 1966), are
   suggested.
C1 Lin, Xiaofeng; S China Normal Univ, Coll Life Sci, Guangzhou, Guangdong,
   510631, China, China.
EM xlin@scnu.edu.cn
RI Pan, Hongbo/L-7928-2017; Pan, Hongbo/F-2054-2013
OI Pan, Hongbo/0000-0001-5047-0463; Pan, Hongbo/0000-0001-5047-0463

SN 1066-5234
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Combination; Available
   name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   /  / ]. 
   Loxophyllum caudatum [Guangdong /  / New species]. 
   Loxophyllum chinense; Loxophyllum rugosum [North Pacific / China,
   Shandong / New species].

   Pleurostomatida

DT Article
TI A NEW NEMATODE OF THE FAMILY TRICHOSTRONGYLIDAE (NEMATODA: STRONGYLIDEA)
   FOUND IN A BLIND SNAKE FROM MANIPUR, INDIA.
AU Lakshmipyari, W. (lakshmi_wah@yahoo.co.in) 
   Gambhir, R.K.
SO Journal of Experimental Zoology India
VL 16
IS 1
PS 59-63
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper describes about a new nematode reported from the
   stomach and small intestine of a Blind snake (Typhlops diardi Schlegel,
   1839) found in Manipur, India. The new nematode closely resembles
   Amphibiophilus Skrjabin, 1916 and Herpetostrongylus Baylis, 1931 but it
   is readily distinguished from the former in cuticle inflated in the
   anterior most part of the body, absence of transverse cuticle with
   striations, buccal capsule rudimentary, vulva equatorial (or slightly
   post-equatorial) in position and female tail tapering to a spike. It
   also differs from the latter in the presence of three well developed
   lips, cuticle inflated in the anterior-most part of the body, absence of
   pre-bursal papillae, presence of simple spicule and vulva equatorial (or
   slightly post-equatorial). The present specimen is also compared with
   Oswaldocruzia Travassos, 1917 and Trichoskrjabinia Travassos, 1937 and
   found some variations from the two also.
C1 Lakshmipyari, W.; Manipur Univ, Dept Life Sci, Canchipur, 795003, India,
   India.
EM lakshmi_wah@yahoo.co.in

   Eurasia; Asia; India

   parasite species] [Manipur /  / New nematode parasite species].

DT Article
TI ANALYSIS OF SOIL CHEMICAL PROPERTIES OF DIFFERENT EARTHWORM HABITATS OF
   WESTERN GHATS, INDIA.
AU Biradar, Madhuri D. (pramodbgai@gmail.com) 
   Giraddi, R.S.
   Gai, P.B.
SO Journal of Experimental Zoology India
VL 16
IS 1
PS 187-191
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Earthworm collections from different locations of Western Ghats of
   Karnataka, India were studied for their identification and soil samples
   collected from the habitats were analyzed for various chemical
   properties like soil pH, EC, organic carbon, N, P, and K. The different
   earthworm species identified from various habitats in the present study
   included Pontoscolex corethrurus, Drawida sp., Chaetocotoides sp.,
   Eudrillus euginae, Megascolex conkanensis, Dichogaster affinis,
   Lennogaster sp., Drawida barwelli belonging to Glossoscolecidae,
   Octochaetidae, Moniligastridae, Eudrillidae and Megascolecidae. Analysis
   of soil chemical characteristics from different habitats of Western
   Ghats indicated substantial variation in different parameters. The soil
   pH values were within the range of 4.5 to 7.9. The soil electrical
   conductivity values and organic carbon contents were in the range of
   0.25 to 0.88 dS/m and 0.87 to 2.97%, respectively. Among the major
   nutrient contents in different habitats, the range of nitrogen content
   was from 121.0 to 337.7 kg/ha, phosphorus content was from 11.5 to 32.1
   kg/ha and potassium content was from 223.4 to 463.2 kg/ha.
C1 Biradar, Madhuri D.; Karnatak Univ, Dept Appl Genet, Dharwad, Karnataka,
   580003, India, India.
EM pramodbgai@gmail.com
SC Agriculture; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0972-0030

   Asia; India

   habitat / Soil chemical property analysis / ] [Karnataka /  / ].

DT Article
TI STUDIES ON TREMATODE PARASITES OF FISHES. ON TWO SPECIES OF THE GENUS,
   ALLOCREADIUM LOOSS, 1900 FROM FRESH WATER FISHES OF UTTAR PRADESH,
   INDIA.
AU Govind, Sabhyata
   Govind, Hare (haregovindvns@rediffmail.com) 
SO Journal of Experimental Zoology India
VL 16
IS 1
PS 211-214
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present communication deals with the description of a new species,
   Allocreadium simhai sp. nov. and an already known form A. mehrai, Gupta,
   1956 collected from the intestine of Mystus vittatus (Bl.) and
   Rhynchobdella Aculeata (Bl.) respectively. Both species has been
   described in detail and the new species has been compared with all the
   known valid species of the genus. The new species differs from A. kosia
   Pande, 1938 and A. nicolli Pande, 1938 in the bipartite vesicula
   seminalis and position of genital pore between intestinal bifurcation
   and ventral sucker, and from A. handiai Pande, 1937; A. thapari Gupta,
   1956 and A. heteropneustusius Agarwal, 1964 in the extension of
   vitelline follicles from the anterior level of ovary and terminal
   position of oral sucker, and from A. seenghali Sabhyata and Govind 2008
   in having terminal oral sucker, smaller, operculate eggs and
   non-confluent vitellaria between the testes.

   India.

DT Article
TI Systematics of Trichoteleia Kieffer and Paridris Kieffer (Hymenoptera,
   Platygastroidea, Platygastridae).
AU Talamas, Elijah J. (elijah.talamas@ars.usda.gov) 
   Masner, Lubomir
   Johnson, Norman F.
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 34
PS 1-79
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Paridris Kieffer and Trichoteleia Kieffer are morphologically similar
   genera of solitary egg parasitoids with little overlap between their
   distributions: Paridris is found commonly worldwide with the exceptions
   of Madagascar, from which a single specimen is known, and New Zealand,
   from which no records are known; Trichoteleia is endemic to the Malagasy
   islands. Here we present the first phylogenetic analysis of
   platygastroid wasps that combines and compares morphological and
   molecular data. We find the results of the phylogenetic analyses of the
   two data sources to be largely congruent for the species treated here.
   Paridris and Trichoteleia are found to be monophyletic, as are two
   morphologically well-defined species groups within Paridris. Neoparidris
   Galloway is found to belong within Paridris and is treated as a junior
   synonym, syn. n. The faunas of Paridris from Africa, Melanesia and the
   Indo-Malay islands are revised. Fifteen species are described of which 9
   are new: Paridris anikulapo Talamas, sp. n. (sub-Saharan Africa);
   Paridris densiclava (Kieffer), (Seychelles); Paridris bispinosa
   (Masner), (Gabon); Paridris nigriclava (Kieffer), (Seychelles); Paridris
   nitidiceps (Kieffer), (Seychelles); Paridris tenuis (Nixon),
   (sub-Saharan Africa); Paridris trispinosa Talamas & Masner, sp. n.,
   (Cameroon, Democratic Republic of the Congo); Paridris bifurcata (Dodd),
   comb. n., (Australia, Papua New Guinea); Paridris mnestros Talamas &
   Masner, sp. n., (Indonesia, Malaysia); Paridris pantex Talamas, sp. n.,
   (Fiji); Paridris phrikos Talamas & Masner, sp. n., (Fiji); Paridris
   skolops Talamas & Masner, sp. n., (Fiji); Paridris sulcata Talamas, sp.
   n., (Vanuatu); Paridris taekuli Talamas & Masner, sp. n., (Australia,
   Bangladesh, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Ivory Coast, Madagascar, New
   Caledonia, Thailand, Vietnam); Paridris xestos Talamas & Masner, sp. n.,
   (Fiji). Paridris flaviclava (Kieffer), syn. n., and P. nigraticeps
   (Kieffer), syn. n., are treated as junior synonyms of P. nigriclava.
C1 Talamas, Elijah J.; Smithsonian Inst, USNM, Washington, DC, 20560, USA,
   USA.
EM elijah.talamas@ars.usda.gov
RI Johnson, Norman/C-3548-2008
OI Johnson, Norman F./0000-0003-1691-5187; Talamas,
   Elijah/0000-0002-1048-6345

DT Article
TI A new brachypterous species of Heterospilus Haliday (Braconidae,
   Doryctinae) from the Neotropical Region.
AU Kula, Robert R. (Robert.Kula@ars.usda.gov) 
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 33
PS 83-90
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species, Heterospilus michaeli Kula, from the Neotropical Region
   is described and differentiated from all other New World species of
   Doryctinae with brachypterous or apterous individuals. It is the first
   species of Heterospilus Haliday in the Neotropical Region known to
   exhibit brachyptery and the fourth described brachypterous species of
   Heterospilus worldwide. Errors and omissions in a recently published
   article on brachypterous and apterous doryctines in the New World are
   corrected.
C1 Kula, Robert R.; ARS, Systemat Entomol Lab, POB 37012,MRC 168,
   Washington, DC, 20013, USA, USA.
EM Robert.Kula@ars.usda.gov

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Vadumasonium Kammerer (Hymenoptera, Braconidae,
   Brachistinae).
AU van Achterbereg, Cornelis (Kees.vanAchterberg@naturalis.nl) 
   Broad, Gavin R.
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 33
PS 91-98
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Vadumasonium Kammerer, 2006 (Braconidae: Brachistinae:
   Diospilini), formerly known only from the Nearctic region, is revised
   and a second species is described from England and Germany: V. vardyorum
   sp. n. The genus is new to the Palaearctic region and we report the
   first host record for the genus. A key to similar genera of the
   Diospilini and to both species is given.

DT Article
TI Revision of Agathacrista new genus (Hymenoptera, Braconidae,
   Agathidinae, Agathidini).
AU Sharkey, Michael J. (msharkey@uky.edu) 
   Stoelb, Stephanie A.C.
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 33
PS 99-112
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Based on a cladistic analysis, a new genus of Agathidini, Agathacrista
   Sharkey, is proposed and its phylogenetic position hypothesized. Two
   previously described (Agathacrista cancellata, Agathacrista
   depressifera) and three new species (Agathacrista sailomi, Agathacrista
   winloni, Agathacrista krataeii) are included. The distribution of
   Agathacrista is limited to the Oriental region and southern portion of
   the eastern Palearctic.
C1 Sharkey, Michael J.; Univ Kentucky, Dept Entomol, Lexington, KY, 40546,
   USA, USA.

DT Article
TI Revision of the Afrotropical Mayrellinae (Cynipoidea, Liopteridae), with
   the first record of Paramblynotus from Madagascar.
AU van Noort, Simon (svannoort@iziko.org.za) 
   Buffington, Matthew L.
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 31
PS 1-64
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The liopterid subfamily Mayrellinae is revised for the Afrotropical
   region including the description of the following nine new species of
   Paramblynotus Cameron: Paramblynotus alexandriensis Buffington & van
   Noort sp. n.; Paramblynotus bayangensis van Noort & Buffington sp. n.;
   Paramblynotus behara van Noort & Buffington sp. n.; Paramblynotus
   dzangasangha van Noort & Buffington sp. n.; Paramblynotus matele van
   Noort & Buffington sp. n.; Paramblynotus parinari Buffington & van Noort
   sp. n.; Paramblynotus ruvubuensis van Noort & Buffington sp. n..;
   Paramblynotus seyrigi van Noort & Buffington sp. n.; Paramblynotus zohy
   van Noort & Buffington sp. n. The genus Paramblynotus is recorded from
   Madagascar for the first time, with representatives of two
   species-groups being present on the island: the Paramblynotus
   yangambicolous species-group and the new Paramblynotus seyrigi
   species-group, which we erect here to accommodate a single, but highly
   distinctive new species possessing apomorphic character states. The
   latter species-group is possibly endemic to Madagascar. We provide
   identification keys to the species-groups and species occurring in the
   Afrotropical region. Online dichotomous and interactive Lucid keys are
   available at http://www.waspweb.org/Cynipoidea/Keys/index.htm

DT Article
TI Cystomastacoides van Achterberg (Braconidae, Rogadinae): first host
   record and descriptions of three new species from Thailand and Papua New
   Guinea.
AU Quicke, Donald L.J. (d.quicke@email.com) 
   Smith, M. Alex
   Hrcek, Jan
   Butcher, Buntika Areekul
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 31
PS 65-78
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of Cystomastacoides van Achterberg, C. asotaphaga Quicke
   sp. n., is described and illustrated based on a series of specimens
   reared from caterpillars of the erebid moth Asota plana Walker from
   Papua New Guinea. Two other new species without biological data are also
   described, C. nicolepeelerae Quicke & Butcher sp. n. also from Papua New
   Guinea, and C. kiddo Quicke & Butcher sp. n. from Thailand. A key is
   provided to the four known species. The new species extend the known
   range of the genus considerably, it having previously been known only
   from a single species from mainland China (Yunnan), and additionally
   provides the first host record for the genus. Other related genera are
   parasitoids of Sphingidae, Lymantriidae and Crambidae.

   Biol Sci, Ascot, Berks, SL5 7PY, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

TI Description of Celonites andreasmuelleri sp n. (Hymenoptera, Vespidae,
   Masarinae) from the Middle East with a key to the Palaearctic species of
   the C. abbreviatus-complex of the subgenus Celonites s. str.
AU Mauss, Volker (volker.mauss@gmx.de) 
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 31
PS 79-95
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Celonites andreasmuelleri, a new species of pollen wasp from Israel and
   Jordan is described. It belongs to the Celonites abbreviatus-complex as
   indicated by a pollen-collecting apparatus consisting of knobbed setae
   on clypeus and frons and a corresponding pollen comb on the forelegs.
   Females of C. andreasmuelleri were recorded at nototribic flowers of
   Ballota sp. (Lamiaceae).
C1 Mauss, Volker; Staatliches Museum Nat Kunde, Abt Entomol, Rosenstein 1,
   Stuttgart, D-70191, Germany, Germany.

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI Description of Apechthis cantika sp n. from Sulawesi Is., Indonesia with
   redescription of the holotype of A. taiwana Uchida (Hymenoptera,
   Ichneumonidae, Pimplinae).
AU Watanabe, Kyohei (himebati-love@hotmail.co.jp) 
   Takasuka, Keizo
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 31
PS 105-117
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Apechthis cantika sp. n. (Ichneumonidae: Pimplinae) is described from
   the island of Sulawesi, Indonesia. This is the first known
   representative of the genus in Indonesia and also the southernmost
   record of Apechthis in the Oriental region, extending the known
   distribution far southwards. Discovery of a second yellow Apechthis in
   the Oriental region, following A. taiwana Uchida, suggests that the
   genus suddenly changes its body colour entirely from black to yellow
   towards the equator, independently in both the Oriental and Neotropical
   regions. The holotype of A. taiwana, apparently closely related to A.
   cantika sp. n., is also redescribed for comparison.
C1 Watanabe, Kyohei; Kobe Univ, Grad Sch Agr Sci, Rokkodaicho 1-1, Kobe,
   Hyogo, 6578501, Japan, Japan.
EM himebati-love@hotmail.co.jp
RI Takasuka, Keizo/P-1519-2018
OI Takasuka, Keizo/0000-0001-8386-1292
SC Zoology
SN 1070-9428
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Apechthis [Indonesia /  / New record]. 
   Apechthis cantika [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Ichneumonoidea, Ichneumonidae

   Apechthis cantika (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 107].

DT Article
TI A revision of the giant Amazonian ants of the genus Dinoponera
   (Hymenoptera, Formicidae).
AU Lenhart, Paul A. (palenhart@neo.tamu.edu) 
   Dash, Shawn T.
   Mackay, William P.
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 31
PS 119-164
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Dinoponera Roger 1861 has been revised several times. However, species
   limits remain questionable due to limited collection and undescribed
   males. We re-evaluate the species boundaries based on workers and known
   males. We describe the new species Dinoponera hispida from Tucurui,
   Para, Brazil and Dinoponera snellingi from Campo Grande, Mato Grosso do
   Sul, Brazil and describe the male of Dinoponera longipes Emery 1901.
   Additionally, we report numerous range extensions with updated
   distribution maps and provide keys in English, Spanish and Portuguese
   for workers and known males of Dinoponera.
C1 Lenhart, Paul A.; Texas A & M Univ, Dept Entomol, 2475 TAMU, College
   Stn, TX, 77843, USA, USA.
EM palenhart@neo.tamu.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1070-9428

   Neotropical region; South America

   Dinoponera hispida; Dinoponera snellingi [Brazil /  / New species].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912065347
DT Article
TI The Aenictus ceylonicus species group (Hymenoptera, Formicidae,
   Aenictinae) from Southeast Asia.
AU Jaitrong, Weeyawat (polyrhachis@yahoo.com) 
   Yamane, Seiki
SO Journal of Hymenoptera Research
VL 31
PS 165-233
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The genus Aenictus is a diverse group of army ants in the Old World
   tropics and subtropics. The Southeast Asian species of the Aenictus
   ceylonicus group are revised to include twenty-three species (4 named
   and 19 new species): Aenictus appressipilosus sp. n., A. baliensis sp.
   n., A. brevipodus sp. n., A. concavus sp. n., A. cylindripetiolus sp.
   n., A. eguchii sp. n., A. formosensis Forel, 1913 stat. n., A.
   fuschuanensis Zhou, 2001, A. gonioccipus sp. n., A. itoi sp. n., A.
   jawadwipa sp. n., A. khaoyaiensis sp. n., A. lifuiae Terayama, 1984, A.
   longicephalus sp. n., A. maneerati sp. n., A. minipetiolus sp. n., A.
   pilosus sp. n., A. pinkaewi sp. n., A. sundalandensis sp. n., A.
   thailandianus Terayama & Kubota, 1993, A. watanasiti sp. n., A. wilaiae
   sp. n., and A. wiwatwitayai sp. n. Aenictus ceylonicus var. formosensis
   Forel is removed from synonymy with A. ceylonicus and raised to frill
   species. Lectotype and paralectotypes are designated for A. ceylonicus.
   Redescriptions of Aenictus ceylonicus (Mayr, 1866) (India and Sri Lanka)
   and A. doryloides Wilson, 1964 (India) are provided. The queen of A.
   cylindripetiolus is described. A key to the Southeast Asian species of
   the group is given based on the worker caste. Most of the Southeast
   Asian species of this species group have more or less limited
   distribution ranges. This may be due to the poor dispersal ability
   generally seen among the Aenictus species, in which the propagule
   (reproductive unit) is an apterous queen plus accompanying workers.
C1 Jaitrong, Weeyawat; Technopolis, Natl Sci Museum, Khlong 5, Khlong
   Luang, Pathum Thani, 12120, Thailand, Thailand.
EM polyrhachis@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1070-9428

   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status; Key; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Aenictus baliensis; Aenictus gonioccipus; Aenictus itoi; Aenictus
   longicephalus; Aenictus minipetiolus [Indonesia /  / New species].

DT Article
TI Resurrection of the genus Nectoneanthes Imajima, 1972 (Nereididae:
   Polychaeta), with redescription of Nectoneanthes oxypoda (Marenzeller,
   1879) and description of a new species, comparing them to Neanthes
   succinea (Leuckart, 1847).
AU Sato, Masanori (sato@sci.kagoshima-u.ac.jp) 
SO Journal of Natural History
VL 47
IS 1-2
PS 1-50
PD Jan 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Nectoneanthes Imajima, 1972, which has been regarded as a synonym of
   Neanthes Kinberg, 1865 and later of Alitta Kinberg, 1865, is resurrected
   in the present study, with evidence showing that the type species of
   Nectoneanthes (N.oxypoda Marenzeller, 1879) is not a synonym of Neanthes
   succinea (Leuckart, 1847), but a valid species. Nectoneanthes oxypoda
   and Neanthes succinea are redescribed with newly found characteristics.
   The following seven species are judged as junior synonyms of
   Nectoneanthes oxypoda: Nectoneanthes latipoda Paik, 1973; Nectoneanthes
   multignatha Wu, Sun and Yang, 1981; Nectoneanthes donghaiensis He, 1987;
   Nereis ijimai Izuka, 1912; Nereis alatopalpis Wesenberg-Lund, 1949;
   Nereis singularis Wesenberg-Lund, 1949, and Nereis (Nereis) legeri
   Gravier and Dantan, 1934. Nectoneanthes is composed of two species:
   Nectoneanthes oxypoda and Nectoneanthes uchiwa sp. nov. which is
   described here. The combination Neanthes succinea is also resurrected,
   reversing the placement in Alitta. Neanthes succinea seems to have been
   introduced recently to Asia and Australia. http://www.zoobank.org/urn:
   lsid: zoobank.org: pub:45D3C54C-AB3B-463E-A744-8A52ACE084DC
C1 Sato, Masanori; Kagoshima Univ, Fac Sci, Kagoshima, 8900065, Japan,
   Japan.
EM sato@sci.kagoshima-u.ac.jp

   dispersal; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   / ].

AB Four new cantharid species are described: Lycocerus parameratus sp. nov.
   (China: Guangdong, Hunan); L. nigroapicis sp. nov. (China: Guangxi); L.
   bifurcatus sp. nov. (China: Guangdong); and L. nigrigenus sp. nov.
   (China: Zhejiang, Fujian), which are provided with photos of habitus of
   males and illustrations of aedeagi and abdominal sternites VIII of
   females. The new species are related to L. kuatunensis (Wittmer, 1995),
   which is provided with a supplementary description and illustration of
   abdominal sternite VIII of the female. A key to the aforementioned five
   species is given. The type localities of the new species Lycocerus
   parameratus sp. nov., L. nigroapicis sp. nov., L. bifurcatus sp. nov.
   and L. nigrigenus sp. nov. and the broadened distribution of L.
   kuatunensis are mapped. http://www.zoobank.org/urn: lsid: zoobank.org:

DT Article
TI Molecular and morphological characterization of Ektaphelenchoides
   andrassyi sp n. (Rhabditida, Aphelenchoididae) from northern Iran.
AU Atighi, M.R.
   Pourjam, E. (Pourjame@modares.ac.ir) 
   Pedram, M.
   Ye, W.
   Aliramaji, F.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 16
IS 1
PS 17-23
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ektaphelenchoides andrassyi sp. n. from northern Iran is described and
   illustrated based on morphological and molecular features. The new
   species is characterized by its body 457-564 [mu]m long in males, lip
   region without a clear constriction separating it from adjacent body in
   lateral view, male stylet 11.5-14.5 [mu]m long, excretory pore at level
   of the posterior part of the metacorpus or 60-75 [mu]m from the anterior
   end, hemizonid at 75-88 [mu]m from the anterior end, shape of posterior
   end in females, shape of tail in males and having three incisures in the
   lateral. field. In the shape of tail in males and females and molecular
   characters, it is similar to E. compsi, E. hunti, E. pini, E. spondylis
   and E. sylvestris, but most closely resembles E. compsi and their
   separation is discussed. Molecular analysis of 335-bp partial ribosomal
   DNA-D3 showed E. andrassyi sp. n. to be different but closest to other
   species of the genus Ektaphelenchoides.
C1 Pourjam, E.; Tarbiat Modares Univ, Coll Agr, Tehran, Iran, Iran.

DT Article
TI Description of two new species of Nothacrobeles Allen & Noffsinger, 1971
   (Rhabditida: Cephalobidae) from Kelso Dunes, Mojave National Preserve,
   California, USA.
AU Bostrom, S. (sven.bostrom@nrm.se) 
   Holovachov, O.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 16
IS 1
PS 25-34
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of the genus Nothacrobeles, N. istvani sp. n. and N.
   andrassyi sp. n., are described from the Kelso Dunes area, Mojave
   National Preserve, southern California. Nothacrobeles istvani sp. n. is
   characterized by a body length of 394-526 [mu]m in females and 318-503
   [mu]m in males; three pairs of asymmetrical lips, pairs of lips
   separated by U-shaped primary axils with two triangular-acute guarding
   processes, each lip asymmetrically rectangular, with seven tines along
   its margin; three labial probolae, exterior surface concave, bifurcated
   into two short prongs almost half of probola diameter: adoral margin
   with four rounded apical tines and exterior margin lacking tines but
   with a wavy appearance, base of each labial probola with a narrow
   pedestal; and postvulval uterine sac 28-64 [mu]m long. Nothacrobeles
   andrassyi sp. n. is distinguished by a body length of 289-355 [mu]m in
   females and 268-305 [mu]m in males; three pairs of asymmetrical lips,
   pairs of lips separated by U-shaped primary axils with two short
   triangular-rounded guarding processes, each lip asymmetrically
   rectangular with four tines along its margin: three short rounded and
   one long acute extending along the primary axil; three labial probolae,
   short and blunt, with a shallow concavity, spatula-shaped; and
   postvulval uterine sac 12-19 [mu]m long.
C1 Bostrom, S.; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Dept Zool, Box 50007, Stockholm,
   SE-10405, Sweden, Sweden.
EM sven.bostrom@nrm.se

DT Article
TI Description of Diplogasteroides andrassyi sp n. (Rhabditida,
   Diplogastridae), associated with Monochamus grandis and Pinaceae trees
   in Japan.
AU Kanzaki, N. (nkanzaki@affrc.go.jp) 
   Tanaka, R.
   Hirooka, Y.
   Maehara, N.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 16
IS 1
PS 35-47
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Diplogasteroides andrassyi sp. n. is described and figured, and its
   molecular barcode and phylogenetic status within the family
   Diplogastridae is determined. The new species is characterized by its
   stomatal morphology, tubelike stoma with three small dorsal teeth and
   two subventral ridges, spicules clearly curved ventrad at one-third from
   the anterior end, gubernaculum with a rounded anterior end and sharply
   pointed distal end in the lateral view, male bearing nine pairs of
   genital papillae <P1, (P2, P3d), C, P4, P5d, ph, (P6, P7, P8), P9d>, and
   females with well-developed receptaculum seminis. The new species is
   close to several wood-boring beetle associates, namely D. adephagus, D.
   carinthiacus, D. frontali, D. haslacheri and D. janae but it can be
   distinguished from them by the arrangement of the male genital papillae,
   spicule morphology and the relative length of the male tail spike, i.e.,
   the ratio of the spike to the total tail length. The phylogenetic
   analysis confirms the paraphyly of the genus Diplogasteroides, and the
   new species is closest to Pseudodiplogasteroides spp.
C1 Kanzaki, N.; Forestry & Forest Prod Res Inst, Forest Pathol Lab, 1
   Matsunosato, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 3058687, Japan, Japan.
EM nkanzaki@affrc.go.jp

   zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Paractinolaimus Meyl, 1957 (Dorylaimida:
   Nematoda) and a compendium of all the nominal species of the genus.
AU Vinciguerra, M.T. (vincimar@unict.it) 
   Clausi, M.
   Orselli, L.
SO Journal of Nematode Morphology and Systematics
VL 16
IS 1
PS 49-57
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Paractinolaimus, P. magistris sp. n., is
   described and illustrated. It is characterized by having body 1.9-2.3 mm
   long; low, truncate lip region; four massive, acute onchia; stoma walls
   covered with sparse tiny denticles; odontostyle 29-35 [mu]m long; well
   developed, didelphic-amphidelphic female reproductive apparatus; vulva a
   longitudinal oval pore; absence of advulval papillae; female tail about
   as long as anal body diameter (c'=1.0-1.1), conoid, curved ventrad, and
   with acute terminus; mail tail convex conoid with blunt terminus; and
   14-15 nearly contiguous ventromedian supplements. The new species, among
   the numerous species of Paractinolaimus described so far, has a unique
   female tail shape: instead of the usual convex conoid initial part
   followed by a more or less elongated slender part, it shows a quite
   short, Eudotylaimus-like conoid tail. A compendium of morphometrics of
   the nominal species of the genus is also provided.
C1 Vinciguerra, M.T.; Univ Catania, Dept Biol Geol & Environm Sci, Via
   Androne 81, Catania, I-95124, Italy, Italy.
